item.title: Random Number Generater (Select Range)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“1337h4x, post:10, topic:24131”]dude your function names are too long.
for getRandomNonZero use getRandNZ plez?[/quote]

And the point of shortening it is? With the full name, anyone who reads the code knows exactly what it does, which isn’t the case with getRandNZ. That’s why there’s no limit to the length of a method name…so you have the ability to describe the function of the method in its signature. Even so, that method name isn’t long at all…nothing like a couple methods in java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor But overly long method names should be avoided too…just a relative description will suffice. That’s also what javadoc is for.

Read full topic

item.title: Random Number Generater (Select Range)
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Those of you who know who I am can probably guess where this code came from…

    public static boolean coinFlip() {
        return (getRandom(2) == 1);
    }

    public static int getRandomRange(int range) {
        return (int)((Math.random() * (range * 2)) - range);
    }

    public static int getRandom(int max) {
        return ((int)(Math.random() * max) + 1) % (max <= 0 ? 1 : max);
    }

    public static int getRandomRangeNonZero(int range) {
        int val = getRandomRange(range);
        while(val == 0)
            val = getRandomRange(range);
        return val;
    }

    public static int getRandomNonZero(int max) {
        int val = getRandom(max);
        while(val == 0)
            val = getRandom(max);
        return val;
    }

coinFlip() - think you can figure it out?
getRandomRange(int range) - returns an int [-range, range)
getRandom(int max) - returns an int [0, max)
getRandomRangeNonZero(int range) - returns a nonzero int [-range, range)
getRandomNonZero(int max) - returns an int [1, max)

Read full topic

item.title: Random Number Generater (Select Range)
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Ah right, gotta subtract 5 from maxValue…but just some pointless info, Math.random() * maxValue can never possible reach maxValue as Random.nextDouble() returns a value in the set [0, 1)…1 is excluded.

and also lol…

5 + Math.random() * maxValue will give you a vaule up to 5 above the max.
min + Math.random() * (maxValue() - min)
Should work. Anywayz, ya

@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“YourDistracted, post:4, topic:24131”]Math.random() * maxValue

Even i knew that and i dont even program…[/quote]
The random class has its own uses like that…and its personal preference which method he wants to use.

Iamadam:

And that generates a number between 0 and maxValue YourDistracted. What if you need a number between 5 and 10?

5 + Math.random() * maxValue
or
5 + new java.util.Random().nextInt(5);

item.title: Random Number Generater (Select Range)
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:
@Kryptizzler wrote:

Not too bad, but if the range is always one, you could just do:

Math.random() * maxValue

Oh, and also, you probably shouldn’t throw an Exception on the main void.

Read full topic

item.title: Random Number Generater (Select Range)
item.dc:creator: @Ulead Ulead
item.description:
@Ulead wrote:

[code]
import java.util.Random;
import javax.swing.;
import java.io.;

public class hello {
public static void main(String[] args)throws IOException{
double numberdicel;
int dice;

	System.out.println("Welcome to Random Generator");

	Reader reader = new InputStreamReader(System.in);
	BufferedReader input = new BufferedReader(reader);

	System.out.print("Enter range 1- ");
	String Range = input.readLine();
	int frange = new Integer(Range).intValue();
	Random Randomize = new Random();
   double Number = Randomize.nextDouble();
   numberdicel = Number * frange;

   double anInt = Math.floor(numberdicel);
   System.out.println(anInt);

}
}[/code]

Read full topic
